trap_list.name: Spear Phishing vs Whaling
trap_list.misconception: Treating any targeted phishing as whaling.
trap_list.fix: Whaling specifically targets senior executives such as CEO/CFO.

trap_list.name: Typosquatting vs Pharming
trap_list.misconception: Assuming all fake-site redirects are caused by mistyped URLs.
trap_list.fix: Typosquatting needs a typo; pharming can redirect even with a correct URL via DNS/hosts manipulation.

trap_list.name: Brute Force vs Password Spraying
trap_list.fix: Brute force attacks one account with many guesses; spraying attacks many accounts with common passwords.

trap_list.name: Online vs Offline Password Attacks
trap_list.misconception: Assuming all password guessing hits live login systems.
trap_list.fix: Offline cracking targets stolen hashes and bypasses live lockout controls.

trap_list.name: Misinformation vs Disinformation
trap_list.misconception: Ignoring intent when classifying influence campaigns.
trap_list.fix: Disinformation is intentional deception; misinformation can be accidental.

missions.name: Social Engineering Principles and Lures
missions.goal: Classify social engineering principles and identify common phishing-style lures.

coaching_tips: If a message pushes speed or fear, pause and verify via a trusted channel.
Map each lure to a principle: authority, urgency, social proof, scarcity, familiarity, trust, intimidation.

missions.name: Attack Delivery Patterns and Influence Ops
missions.goal: Differentiate watering hole, brand impersonation, typosquatting, pharming, and MDM workflows.

coaching_tips: Typosquatting needs a typo; pharming redirects even with the right URL.
For misinformation/disinformation, classify intent first, then apply TRUST response steps.

missions.name: Password Attack Tactics and Defenses
missions.goal: Separate brute force vs spraying and map hashing controls to realistic cracking scenarios.

coaching_tips: Brute force = many guesses, one account; spraying = few common guesses, many accounts.
Offline cracking is faster once hashes are stolen, so hardening storage and hashing is critical.

missions.name: Understanding Drill: Matching, Ordering, and Scenario Reasoning
missions.goal: Apply social engineering and password-defense concepts in interactive formats.

boss.premise: Resolve mixed social engineering and password attack scenarios under time pressure.

rationaleIncorrect.Password spraying: Spraying uses low-volume attempts across many users, so smart lockout and detection are key.
rationaleIncorrect.Credential stuffing: Stuffing relies on reused credentials from breaches; MFA and password reuse prevention are critical.
rationaleIncorrect.MFA fatigue: Fatigue exploits user behavior, so push-number matching and user training are high-value controls.

Detection for low-and-slow attempts across many accounts

question_bank.stem: Order these security awareness program actions from design to continuous improvement.
question_bank.explanation: Awareness programs are most effective when they are measured and iterated, not treated as one-time training.
question_bank.rationaleCorrect: Program lifecycle should move from baseline to targeted training, simulation, and measurable iteration.

rationaleIncorrect.Establish baseline user-risk metrics: You need baseline metrics first to know if training changes behavior.
rationaleIncorrect.Deliver role-specific training and job a: Training should be tailored after baseline risk is known.
rationaleIncorrect.Run controlled phishing simulations with: Simulation validates whether training transfers to real behavior.
rationaleIncorrect.Review outcomes and tune the next campai: Iteration is the final step that keeps the program improving.

question_bank.stem: A help desk analyst receives a suspected phishing report. Put the response steps in the best initial order.
items: Preserve the reported message and metadata
Contain immediate risk by blocking sender, URL, or hash
Identify other impacted users and systems
Document actions and notify incident response stakeholders
correct_order: Preserve the reported message and metadata
Contain immediate risk by blocking sender, URL, or hash
Identify other impacted users and systems
Document actions and notify incident response stakeholders
question_bank.explanation: Good incident handling starts by preserving evidence, then reducing blast radius, then scoping impact, then communicating and recording decisions.
question_bank.rationaleCorrect: This sequence balances evidence integrity with speed. You keep forensic value while still reducing ongoing risk.

rationaleIncorrect.Preserve the reported message and metada: Skipping evidence preservation early can break later analysis and prevent reliable timeline reconstruction.
rationaleIncorrect.Contain immediate risk by blocking sende: Containment is high priority, but doing it before evidence capture can erase key indicators.
rationaleIncorrect.Identify other impacted users and system: Scoping before containment can allow continued credential theft or malware delivery.
rationaleIncorrect.Document actions and notify incident res: Documentation is essential, but it follows concrete evidence and containment work.

sourceRef.title: Phishing triage sequence

hints: Start by preserving evidence before making environment changes.
Contain active risk before broad impact analysis and stakeholder reporting.

question_bank.stem: Order these password hardening actions from foundation to advanced protection.
items: Set minimum length and banned-password policy
Require MFA for remote and privileged access
Enable account lockout or throttling controls
Monitor authentication logs for spray/stuffing patterns
correct_order: Set minimum length and banned-password policy
Enable account lockout or throttling controls
Require MFA for remote and privileged access
Monitor authentication logs for spray/stuffing patterns
question_bank.explanation: Start with baseline password quality, then rate-limit guessing, then add a second factor, then continuously monitor for abuse.
question_bank.rationaleCorrect: The order reflects layered defense: policy, preventive controls, stronger authentication, then detection and tuning.

rationaleIncorrect.Set minimum length and banned-password p: Without baseline hygiene, other controls still inherit weak credentials.
rationaleIncorrect.Require MFA for remote and privileged ac: MFA is strong, but applying it before baseline policy and lockout leaves avoidable gaps.
rationaleIncorrect.Enable account lockout or throttling con: Rate limiting works best after baseline policy definition so thresholds are meaningful.
rationaleIncorrect.Monitor authentication logs for spray/st: Monitoring should validate and improve controls after they are deployed.

sourceRef.title: Password defense layering

hints: Establish baseline identity policy before advanced detection tuning.
Think in layers: policy, throttling, stronger auth, then telemetry.

question_bank.stem: A suspected business email compromise (BEC) payment request arrives. Choose the safest order of actions.
items: Pause payment execution and flag as suspicious
Verify request through an out-of-band trusted channel
Check sender/domain anomalies and mailbox activity
Escalate confirmed fraud attempt and update controls/training
correct_order: Pause payment execution and flag as suspicious
Verify request through an out-of-band trusted channel
Check sender/domain anomalies and mailbox activity
Escalate confirmed fraud attempt and update controls/training
question_bank.explanation: Financial fraud handling should stop loss first, then verify independently, then investigate artifacts, then harden process and awareness.
question_bank.rationaleCorrect: This ordering prevents immediate loss while preserving room to verify and improve process controls.

rationaleIncorrect.Pause payment execution and flag as susp: If you skip this first, money can leave before verification finishes.
rationaleIncorrect.Verify request through an out-of-band tr: Verification is critical, but only after freezing execution risk.
rationaleIncorrect.Check sender/domain anomalies and mailbo: Technical checks support confidence but do not replace direct verification.
rationaleIncorrect.Escalate confirmed fraud attempt and upd: Escalation closes the loop; doing it before verification causes noise and confusion.

sourceRef.title: BEC payment verification

hints: Reduce financial exposure first, then validate identity out-of-band.
Deep artifact review belongs after transaction risk is paused.

question_bank.stem: Match each social engineering tactic to its best description.
right: Claims senior status to override normal process
Creates fear of missing a limited opportunity
Suggests others already complied so you should too
Pushes immediate action before proper verification

pairs.Authority: Claims senior status to override normal process
pairs.Scarcity: Creates fear of missing a limited opportunity
pairs.Social proof: Suggests others already complied so you should too
pairs.Urgency: Pushes immediate action before proper verification

question_bank.explanation: The attacker goal is to replace critical thinking with emotion-driven compliance. Correctly labeling each tactic helps defenders choose the right countermeasure.
question_bank.rationaleCorrect: Each pairing maps a persuasion lever to its characteristic behavior in phishing and pretexting campaigns.

rationaleIncorrect.Authority: Authority is specifically about abusing hierarchy, not just speed or popularity.
rationaleIncorrect.Scarcity: Scarcity manipulates limited-time pressure, not organizational role.
rationaleIncorrect.Social proof: Social proof leans on herd behavior signals, not direct command.
rationaleIncorrect.Urgency: Urgency centers on compressed timelines to bypass verification.

sourceRef.title: Social engineering persuasion tactics

hints: Map each tactic to the persuasion lever being exploited.
Classify pressure by hierarchy, scarcity, crowd behavior, or time pressure.

question_bank.stem: Match each password attack to the most accurate profile.
right: Tries many passwords against one account
Tries one common password across many accounts
Reuses breached username/password pairs against another service

pairs.Brute force: Tries many passwords against one account
pairs.Password spraying: Tries one common password across many accounts
pairs.Credential stuffing: Reuses breached username/password pairs against another service

question_bank.explanation: These attacks differ by data source and guessing strategy. Knowing the pattern points to the right mitigation (MFA, lockout, and salted hashes).
question_bank.rationaleCorrect: Correct mapping distinguishes guessing attacks from reused-credential attacks and hash cracking workflows.

rationaleIncorrect.Brute force: Brute force focuses depth on one account rather than broad account coverage.
rationaleIncorrect.Password spraying: Spraying avoids lockouts by keeping password attempts low per account.
rationaleIncorrect.Credential stuffing: Stuffing depends on previously leaked credentials, not random guessing.
rationaleIncorrect.Rainbow table attack: Rainbow tables are hash-focused and weakened by salting.

sourceRef.title: Password attack taxonomy

hints: Separate methods by input source: guessed secrets, leaked creds, or hash material.
One approach spreads across many users while another targets one account deeply.

question_bank.stem: Match each phishing channel to its usual delivery medium.
question_bank.explanation: Channel names map to where the social engineering happens. Whaling is still phishing, but with high-value executive targeting.
question_bank.rationaleCorrect: Each pairing aligns with the communication channel the attacker exploits.

rationaleIncorrect.Phishing: Generic phishing is usually broad email-based targeting.
rationaleIncorrect.Smishing: Smishing is text-message phishing, not voice.
rationaleIncorrect.Vishing: Vishing occurs over calls and voicemail workflows.
rationaleIncorrect.Whaling: Whaling focuses on senior leaders and high-impact approvals.

sourceRef.title: Phishing channel map

hints: Identify the communication medium first, then targeting scope.
One variant is defined by executive targeting rather than medium.

question_bank.stem: Which controls are most effective against credential stuffing? (Choose two.)

options.C: Rate limiting and anomaly detection on auth endpoints
options.D: Allowing legacy protocols without modern auth
options.E: Publishing password complexity hints in public docs

question_bank.explanation: Credential stuffing succeeds when leaked credentials are reusable at scale. MFA and login-abuse detection disrupt both reuse and automation.
question_bank.rationaleCorrect: These two controls specifically reduce account takeover risk from reused credentials and scripted login attempts.

rationaleIncorrect.A: MFA is a strong anti-takeover control against reused passwords.
rationaleIncorrect.B: Password reuse increases stuffing success, so this is harmful.
rationaleIncorrect.C: Rate limiting and behavioral detection directly reduce automated abuse.
rationaleIncorrect.D: Legacy protocols commonly bypass strong modern controls.
rationaleIncorrect.E: Public hints can assist attackers without improving defense.

sourceRef.title: Credential stuffing mitigations

hints: Select controls that block reused credentials and automated auth abuse.
Skip choices that weaken authentication or expose defensive details.

question_bank.stem: A workforce reports many suspicious messages. Which actions improve resilience the most? (Choose two.)

options.A: Run short role-based phishing simulations with feedback
options.B: Disable all external email attachments permanently
options.C: Publish a one-click reporting workflow in mail clients
options.D: Rely only on annual policy acknowledgement
options.E: Ignore false positives to avoid analyst workload

question_bank.explanation: Behavior improves with frequent practical drills and easy reporting paths. Those two controls increase detection speed and user confidence.
question_bank.rationaleCorrect: Training plus simple reporting creates fast detection loops without depending on perfect user judgment.

rationaleIncorrect.A: Frequent practice builds pattern recognition and better reporting habits.
rationaleIncorrect.B: Blanket attachment bans often break business and drive risky workarounds.
rationaleIncorrect.C: Low-friction reporting is one of the highest leverage controls.
rationaleIncorrect.D: Annual acknowledgment alone does not build real response muscle memory.
rationaleIncorrect.E: Ignoring reports hides useful indicators and degrades trust in reporting.

sourceRef.title: Awareness and reporting loop

hints: Pick options that improve both user practice and reporting speed.
Prioritize repeatable workflows over annual policy-only efforts.

question_bank.stem: Scenario: A finance employee receives an "urgent" vendor bank-change request from a familiar display name. The reply-to domain differs slightly from the legitimate one. What is the best next action?

options.A: Process the change to avoid late-payment penalties
options.B: Forward the message to coworkers to ask if it looks real
options.C: Verify the change using a trusted out-of-band contact method
options.D: Reply to the same email asking for more details

question_bank.explanation: Display names and similar domains are common BEC tricks. Independent verification over a trusted channel breaks the attack path.
question_bank.rationaleCorrect: Out-of-band verification prevents business process abuse by validating intent through a known-good contact path.

rationaleIncorrect.A: Speed without verification is exactly what BEC campaigns exploit.
rationaleIncorrect.B: Peer opinion is not identity verification and can spread attacker content.
rationaleIncorrect.C: This is the safest control when payment or identity changes are requested.
rationaleIncorrect.D: Replying in-thread keeps you inside attacker-controlled communication.

sourceRef.title: Vendor payment change verification

hints: Treat display names as weak identity proof and verify independently.
Avoid actions that keep verification in the same suspicious thread.

question_bank.stem: Scenario: A user receives an MFA push they did not initiate and then gets a call claiming to be IT asking them to approve it "to fix sync." What should the user do first?

options.A: Approve once, then immediately reset password
options.B: Deny the push and report a suspected account takeover attempt
options.C: Ignore the push and wait for IT to call back
options.D: Approve if the caller knows the employee ID

question_bank.explanation: Unexpected MFA prompts combined with social pressure often indicate MFA fatigue attacks. Deny and report immediately to trigger containment.
question_bank.rationaleCorrect: Rejecting unauthorized prompts and escalating quickly reduces attacker dwell time and protects downstream systems.

rationaleIncorrect.A: Approving even once can hand attackers a valid session.
rationaleIncorrect.B: Deny plus report is the safest and fastest containment path.
rationaleIncorrect.C: Silence without reporting delays response and keeps risk hidden.
rationaleIncorrect.D: Partial personal details are easy to gather and are not proof of legitimacy.

sourceRef.title: MFA fatigue social engineering

hints: Unexpected MFA prompts plus social pressure usually signal an attack in progress.
Immediate denial and escalation protects downstream systems fastest.
